Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Courses          >           Course Detail                                        First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminar: The City and the Grassroots                                Semester and Year        FA 2011                    Course Number        FIRST-UG50                    Section        001                    Instructor        René Francisco Poitevin                    Days                            Mon,Wed                                 Time                            2:00 PM -       3:15 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                         Notes/Restrictions       Open to Gallatin first-year students only.                    Description       This course uses literature, social theory, and film to explore the role of “urban space” in mediating social movements and everyday life. We’ll address the following questions: What makes a city “urban”? Is “urban consciousness” a necessary condition for understanding how society works and who modern people are? How can we understand the city as an object of social conflict and social change, and yet also as a political community seeking to shape its own destiny? Possible readings include Saskia Sassen’s  The Global City  , James Baldwin’s  The Fire Next Time  , Jacobs’  The Death and Life of Great American Cities,  Henry Chang’s  Chinatown Beat,  David Harvey’s  Urbanization of Capital  , and Ernesto Quiñonez’s  Bodega Dreams  .                   Course Type       First-Year Program: Interdisciplinary Seminars (FIRST-UG)                               top of page                                                                   NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin. Digg This     Reddit        Stumble Upon     Technorati     Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Undergraduate          >            Community Learning Initiative                            Community Learning Initiative                                 Gallatin’s Community Learning Initiative (CLI) offers courses that bridge the gap between the classroom and the community by offering students the opportunity to engage in a variety of action-study projects based in New York City. Courses combine academic readings and theory based discussions with practical work in grassroots community organizations, social agencies, and educational institutions. Faculty work closely with students and community organizations to address real-world problems and devise and implement practical solutions.   Fall 2014 Community Learning Courses                                                                              Course #                           Title                               Instructor                                  Day                                  Time                                                                        CLI-UG1444              Lyrics on Lockdown                                                Piper Anderson                                                                  Mon                                                    6:20PM–9:00PM                                                  To participate in this course you must be available on Friday afternoons from 2:30-6pm for visits to Rikers in November-December. Students are also required to attend two Saturday workshop prep sessions in October from 10-5pm.                                                CLI-UG1445              Shifting Focus: Video Production and Community Activism                                                Mark Read                                                                  Tue                                                    3:30PM–6:10PM                                                                        CLI-UG1460              Literacy in Action                                                Dianne Ramdeholl                                                                  Mon                                                    6:20PM–9:00PM                                                                          top of page                                                                                   NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin.
